Reproductive system and breast disorders.1: Asymptomatic or mild symptoms; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Reproductive system and breast disorders.2: Moderate; minimal, local or noninvasive intervention indicated; limiting age-appropriate instrumental ADL
Reproductive system and breast disorders.3: Severe or medically significant but not immediately life-threatening; hospitalization or prolongation of existing hospitalization indicated; disabling; limiting self care ADL

Adult respiratory distress syndrome.3: Present with radiologic findings; intubation not indicated
Adult respiratory distress syndrome.4: Life-threatening respiratory or hemodynamic compromise; intubation or urgent intervention indicated

Apnea.4: Life-threatening respiratory or hemodynamic compromise; intubation or urgent intervention indicated

Aspiration.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Aspiration.2: Altered eating habits; coughing or choking episodes after eating or swallowing; medical intervention indicated (e.g., suction or oxygen)
Aspiration.3: Dyspnea and pneumonia symptoms (e.g., aspiration pneumonia); hospitalization indicated; unable to aliment orally
Aspiration.4: Life-threatening respiratory or hemodynamic compromise; intubation or urgent intervention indicated

Atelectasis.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Atelectasis.2: Symptomatic (e.g., dyspnea, cough); medical intervention indicated (e.g., chest physiotherapy, suctioning); bronchoscopic suctioning
Atelectasis.3: Oxygen indicated; hospitalization or elective operative intervention indicated (e.g., stent, laser)
Atelectasis.4: Life-threatening respiratory or hemodynamic compromise; intubation or urgent intervention indicated

Bronchial fistula.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Bronchial fistula.2: Symptomatic; tube thoracostomy or medical management indicated; limiting instrumental ADL
Bronchial fistula.3: Severe symptoms; limiting self care ADL; endoscopic or operative intervention indicated (e.g., stent or primary closure)
Bronchial fistula.4: Life-threatening consequences; urgent operative intervention with thoracoplasty, chronic open drainage or multiple thoracotomies indicated

Bronchial obstruction.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Bronchial obstruction.2: Symptomatic (e.g., mild wheezing); endoscopic evaluation indicated; radiographic evidence of atelectasis/lobar collapse; medical management indicated (e.g., steroids, bronchodilators)
Bronchial obstruction.3: Shortness of breath with stridor; endoscopic intervention indicated (e.g., laser, stent placement)
Bronchial obstruction.4: Life-threatening respiratory or hemodynamic compromise; intubation or urgent intervention indicated

Bronchial stricture.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Bronchial stricture.2: Symptomatic (e.g., rhonchi or wheezing) but without respiratory distress; medical intervention indicated (e.g., steroids, bronchodilators)
Bronchial stricture.3: Shortness of breath with stridor; endoscopic intervention indicated (e.g., laser, stent placement)
Bronchial stricture.4: Life-threatening respiratory or hemodynamic compromise; intubation or urgent intervention indicated

Bronchopleural fistula.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Bronchopleural fistula.2: Symptomatic; tube thoracostomy or medical intervention indicated; limiting instrumental ADL
Bronchopleural fistula.3: Severe symptoms; limiting self care ADL; endoscopic or operative intervention indicated (e.g., stent or primary closure)
Bronchopleural fistula.4: Life-threatening consequences; urgent operative intervention with thoracoplasty, chronic open drainage or multiple thoracotomies indicated

Bronchopulmonary hemorrhage.3: Transfusion, radiologic, endoscopic, or operative intervention indicated (e.g., hemostasis of bleeding site)
Bronchopulmonary hemorrhage.4: Life-threatening respiratory or hemodynamic compromise; intubation or urgent intervention indicated

Bronchospasm.2: Symptomatic; medical intervention indicated; limiting instrumental ADL
Bronchospasm.3: Limiting self care ADL; oxygen saturation decreased
Bronchospasm.4: Life-threatening respiratory or hemodynamic compromise; intubation or urgent intervention indicated

Chylothorax.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Chylothorax.2: Symptomatic; thoracentesis or tube drainage indicated
Chylothorax.3: Severe symptoms; elective operative intervention indicated
Chylothorax.4: Life-threatening respiratory or hemodynamic compromise; intubation or urgent intervention indicated

Cough.2: Moderate symptoms, medical intervention indicated; limiting instrumental ADL
Cough.3: Severe symptoms; limiting self care ADL

Dyspnea.1: Shortness of breath with moderate exertion
Dyspnea.2: Shortness of breath with minimal exertion; limiting instrumental ADL
Dyspnea.3: Shortness of breath at rest; limiting self care ADL

Epistaxis.2: Moderate symptoms; medical intervention indicated (e.g., nasal packing, cauterization; topical vasoconstrictors)
Epistaxis.3: Transfusion, radiologic, endoscopic, or operative intervention indicated (e.g., hemostasis of bleeding site)

Hiccups.2: Moderate symptoms; medical intervention indicated; limiting instrumental ADL
Hiccups.3: Severe symptoms; interfering with sleep; limiting self care ADL

Hoarseness.1: Mild or intermittent voice change; fully understandable; self-resolves
Hoarseness.2: Moderate or persistent voice changes; may require occasional repetition but understandable on telephone; medical evaluation indicated
Hoarseness.3: Severe voice changes including predominantly whispered speech

Hypoxia.2: Decreased oxygen saturation with exercise (e.g., pulse oximeter <88%); intermittent supplemental oxygen
Hypoxia.3: Decreased oxygen saturation at rest (e.g., pulse oximeter <88% or PaO2 <=55 mm Hg)
Hypoxia.4: Life-threatening airway compromise; urgent intervention indicated (e.g., tracheotomy or intubation)

Laryngeal edema.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Laryngeal edema.2: Symptomatic; medical intervention indicated (e.g., dexamethasone, epinephrine, antihistamines)
Laryngeal edema.4: Life-threatening airway compromise; urgent intervention indicated (e.g., tracheotomy or intubation)

Laryngeal fistula.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Laryngeal fistula.2: Symptomatic; tube thoracostomy or medical management indicated; limiting instrumental ADL
Laryngeal fistula.3: Severe symptoms; limiting self care ADL; endoscopic or operative intervention indicated (e.g., stent or primary closure)
Laryngeal fistula.4: Life-threatening consequences; urgent operative intervention indicated (e.g., thoracoplasty, chronic open drainage or multiple thoracotomies)

Laryngeal hemorrhage.1: Mild cough or trace hemoptysis; laryngoscopic findings
Laryngeal hemorrhage.3: Transfusion, radiologic, endoscopic, or operative intervention indicated (e.g., hemostasis of bleeding site)
Laryngeal hemorrhage.4: Life-threatening airway compromise; urgent intervention indicated (e.g., tracheotomy or intubation)

Laryngeal inflammation.3: Severe throat pain; endoscopic intervention indicated

Laryngeal mucositis.1: Endoscopic findings only; mild discomfort with normal intake
Laryngeal mucositis.3: Severe pain; severely altered eating/swallowing; medical intervention indicated
Laryngeal mucositis.4: Life-threatening airway compromise; urgent intervention indicated (e.g., tracheotomy or intubation)

Laryngeal obstruction.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Laryngeal obstruction.2: Symptomatic (e.g., noisy airway breathing), but causing no respiratory distress; medical management indicated (e.g., steroids); limiting instrumental ADL
Laryngeal obstruction.3: Limiting self care ADL; stridor; endoscopic intervention indicated (e.g., stent, laser)

Laryngeal stenosis.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Laryngeal stenosis.2: Symptomatic (e.g., noisy airway breathing), but causing no respiratory distress; medical management indicated (e.g., steroids)
Laryngeal stenosis.3: Limiting self care ADL; stridor; endoscopic intervention indicated (e.g., stent, laser)

Laryngopharyngeal dysesthesia.1: Mild symptoms, no anxiety; intervention not indicated
Laryngopharyngeal dysesthesia.2: Moderate symptoms; mild anxiety, but no dyspnea; short duration of observation and or anxiolytic indicated; limiting instrumental ADL
Laryngopharyngeal dysesthesia.3: Severe symptoms; dyspnea and swallowing difficulty; limiting self care ADL

Laryngospasm.3: Recurrent episodes; noninvasive intervention indicated (e.g., breathing technique, pressure point massage)
Laryngospasm.4: Persistent or severe episodes associated with syncope; urgent intervention indicated (e.g., fiberoptic laryngoscopy, intubation, botox injection)

Mediastinal hemorrhage.1: Radiologic evidence only; minimal symptoms; intervention not indicated
Mediastinal hemorrhage.3: Transfusion, radiologic, endoscopic, or elective operative intervention indicated (e.g., hemostasis of bleeding site)

Nasal congestion.3: Associated with bloody nasal discharge or epistaxis

Pharyngeal fistula.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Pharyngeal fistula.2: Symptomatic; tube thoracostomy or medical intervention indicated; limiting instrumental ADL
Pharyngeal fistula.3: Severe symptoms; limiting self care ADL; endoscopic or operative intervention indicated (e.g., stent or primary closure)

Pharyngeal hemorrhage.3: Transfusion, radiologic, endoscopic, or operative intervention indicated (e.g., hemostasis of bleeding site)
Pharyngeal hemorrhage.4: Life-threatening respiratory or hemodynamic compromise; intubation or urgent intervention indicated

Pharyngeal mucositis.1: Endoscopic findings only; minimal symptoms with normal oral intake; mild pain but analgesics not indicated
Pharyngeal mucositis.2: Moderate pain and analgesics indicated; altered oral intake; limiting instrumental ADL
Pharyngeal mucositis.3: Severe pain; unable to adequately aliment or hydrate orally; limiting self care ADL

Pharyngeal necrosis.3: Inability to aliment adequately by GI tract; tube feeding or TPN indicated; radiologic, endoscopic, or operative intervention indicated
Pharyngeal necrosis.4: Life-threatening consequences; urgent operative intervention indicated

Pharyngeal stenosis.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Pharyngeal stenosis.2: Symptomatic (e.g., noisy airway breathing), but causing no respiratory distress; medical management indicated (e.g., steroids); limiting instrumental ADL
Pharyngeal stenosis.3: Limiting self care ADL; stridor; endoscopic intervention indicated (e.g., stent, laser)
Pharyngeal stenosis.4: Life-threatening airway compromise; urgent intervention indicated (e.g., tracheotomy or intubation)

Pharyngolaryngeal pain.3: Severe pain; limiting self care ADL

Pleural effusion.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Pleural effusion.2: Symptomatic; intervention indicated (e.g., diuretics or limited therapeutic thoracentesis)
Pleural effusion.3: Symptomatic with respiratory distress and hypoxia; surgical intervention including chest tube or pleurodesis indicated
Pleural effusion.4: Life-threatening respiratory or hemodynamic compromise; intubation or urgent intervention indicated

Pleural hemorrhage.1: Asymptomatic; mild hemorrhage confirmed by thoracentesis
Pleural hemorrhage.2: Symptomatic or associated with pneumothorax; chest tube drainage indicated
Pleural hemorrhage.3: >1000 ml of blood evacuated; persistent bleeding (150-200 ml/hr for 2 - 4 hr); persistent transfusion indicated; elective operative intervention indicated
Pleural hemorrhage.4: Life-threatening respiratory or hemodynamic compromise; intubation or urgent intervention indicated

Pleuritic pain.3: Severe pain; limiting self care ADL

Pneumonitis.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Pneumonitis.2: Symptomatic; medical intervention indicated; limiting instrumental ADL
Pneumonitis.3: Severe symptoms; limiting self care ADL; oxygen indicated
Pneumonitis.4: Life-threatening respiratory compromise; urgent intervention indicated (e.g., tracheotomy or intubation)

Pneumothorax.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Pneumothorax.2: Symptomatic; intervention indicated (e.g., tube placement without sclerosis)
Pneumothorax.3: Sclerosis and/or operative intervention indicated; hospitalization indicated

Productive cough.1: Occasional/minimal production of sputum with cough
Productive cough.2: Moderate sputum production; limiting instrumental ADL
Productive cough.3: Persistent or copious production of sputum; limiting self care ADL

Pulmonary edema.1: Radiologic findings only; minimal dyspnea on exertion
Pulmonary edema.2: Moderate dyspnea on exertion; medical intervention indicated; limiting instrumental ADL
Pulmonary edema.3: Severe dyspnea or dyspnea at rest; oxygen indicated; limiting self care ADL
Pulmonary edema.4: Life-threatening respiratory compromise; urgent intervention or intubation with ventilatory support indicated

Pulmonary fibrosis.1: Mild hypoxemia; radiologic pulmonary fibrosis < 25% of lung volume
Pulmonary fibrosis.2: Moderate hypoxemia; evidence of pulmonary hypertension; radiographic pulmonary fibrosis 25-50%
Pulmonary fibrosis.3: Severe hypoxemia; evidence of right-sided heart failure; radiographic pulmonary fibrosis >50 - 75%
Pulmonary fibrosis.4: Life-threatening consequences (e.g., hemodynamic/pulmonary complications); intubation with ventilatory support indicated; radiographic pulmonary fibrosis >75% with severe honeycombing

Pulmonary fistula.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Pulmonary fistula.2: Symptomatic; tube thoracostomy or medical management indicated; limiting instrumental ADL
Pulmonary fistula.3: Limiting self care ADL; endoscopic stenting or operative intervention indicated
Pulmonary fistula.4: Life-threatening consequences; urgent operative intervention indicated

Pulmonary hypertension.1: Minimal dyspnea; findings on physical exam or other evaluation
Pulmonary hypertension.2: Moderate dyspnea, cough; requiring evaluation by cardiac catheterization and medical intervention
Pulmonary hypertension.3: Severe symptoms, associated with hypoxemia, right heart failure; oxygen indicated
Pulmonary hypertension.4: Life-threatening airway consequences; urgent intervention indicated (e.g., tracheotomy or intubation)

Respiratory failure.4: Life-threatening consequences; urgent intervention, intubation, or ventilatory support indicated

Retinoic acid syndrome.1: Fluid retention; <3 kg of weight gain; intervention with fluid restriction and/or diuretics indicated
Retinoic acid syndrome.2: Moderate signs or symptoms; steroids indicated

Sinus disorder.2: Symptomatic stenosis or edema/narrowing interfering with airflow; limiting instrumental ADL
Sinus disorder.3: Stenosis with significant nasal obstruction; limiting self care ADL
Sinus disorder.4: Necrosis of soft tissue or bone; urgent operative intervention indicated

Sleep apnea.1: Snoring and nocturnal sleep arousal without apneic periods
Sleep apnea.2: Moderate apnea and oxygen desaturation; excessive daytime sleepiness; medical evaluation indicated; limiting instrumental ADL
Sleep apnea.3: Oxygen desaturation; associated with hypertension; medical intervention indicated; limiting self care ADL
Sleep apnea.4: Cardiovascular or neuropsychiatric symptoms; urgent operative intervention indicated

Sore throat.3: Severe pain; limiting self care ADL; limiting ability to swallow

Stridor.3: Respiratory distress limiting self care ADL; medical intervention indicated
Stridor.4: Life-threatening airway compromise; urgent intervention indicated (e.g., tracheotomy or intubation)

Tracheal fistula.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Tracheal fistula.2: Symptomatic; tube thoracostomy or medical intervention indicated; limiting instrumental ADL
Tracheal fistula.3: Severe symptoms; limiting self care ADL; endoscopic or operative intervention indicated (e.g., stent or primary closure)
Tracheal fistula.4: Life-threatening consequences; urgent operative intervention indicated (e.g., thoracoplasty, chronic open drainage or multiple thoracotomies)

Tracheal mucositis.1: Endoscopic findings only; minimal hemoptysis, pain, or respiratory symptoms
Tracheal mucositis.2: Moderate symptoms; medical intervention indicated; limiting instrumental ADL
Tracheal mucositis.3: Severe pain; hemorrhage or respiratory symptoms; limiting self care ADL

Tracheal stenosis.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Tracheal stenosis.2: Symptomatic (e.g., noisy airway breathing), but causing no respiratory distress; medical management indicated (e.g., steroids)
Tracheal stenosis.3: Stridor or respiratory distress limiting self care ADL; endoscopic intervention indicated (e.g., stent, laser)
Tracheal stenosis.4: Life-threatening airway compromise; urgent intervention indicated (e.g., tracheotomy or intubation)

Voice alteration.1: Mild or intermittent change from normal voice
Voice alteration.2: Moderate or persistent change from normal voice; still understandable
Voice alteration.3: Severe voice changes including predominantly whispered speech; may require frequent repetition or face-to-face contact for understandability; may require assistive technology

Wheezing.1: Detectable airway noise with minimal symptoms
Wheezing.2: Moderate symptoms; medical intervention indicated; limiting instrumental ADL
Wheezing.3: Severe respiratory symptoms limiting self care ADL; oxygen therapy or hospitalization indicated

Respiratory, thoracic and mediastinal di.1: Asymptomatic or mild symptoms; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Respiratory, thoracic and mediastinal di.2: Moderate; minimal, local or noninvasive intervention indicated; limiting age-appropriate instrumental ADL
Respiratory, thoracic and mediastinal di.3: Severe or medically significant but not immediately life-threatening; hospitalization or prolongation of existing hospitalization indicated; disabling; limiting self care ADL

Alopecia.1: Hair loss of up to 50% of normal for that individual that is not obvious from a distance but only on close inspection; a different hair style may be required to cover the hair loss but it does not require a wig or hair piece to camouflage
Alopecia.2: Hair loss of >50% normal for that individual that is readily apparent to others; a wig or hair piece is necessary if the patient desires to completely camouflage the hair loss; associated with psychosocial impact

Body odor.1: Mild odor; physician intervention not indicated; self care interventions
Body odor.2: Pronounced odor; psychosocial impact; patient seeks medical intervention

Bullous dermatitis.2: Blisters covering 10-30% BSA; painful blisters; limiting instrumental ADL
Bullous dermatitis.3: Blisters covering >30% BSA; limiting self care ADL
Bullous dermatitis.4: Blisters covering >30% BSA; associated with fluid or electrolyte abnormalities; ICU care or burn unit indicated

Dry skin.1: Covering <10% BSA and no associated erythema or pruritus
Dry skin.2: Covering 10-30% BSA and associated with erythema or pruritus; limiting instrumental ADL
Dry skin.3: Covering >30% BSA and associated with pruritus; limiting self care ADL

Erythema multiforme.1: Target lesions covering <10% BSA and not associated with skin tenderness
Erythema multiforme.2: Target lesions covering 10-30% BSA and associated with skin tenderness
Erythema multiforme.3: Target lesions covering >30% BSA and associated with oral or genital erosions
Erythema multiforme.4: Target lesions covering >30% BSA; associated with fluid or electrolyte abnormalities; ICU care or burn unit indicated

Erythroderma.2: Erythema covering >90% BSA without associated symptoms; limiting instrumental ADL
Erythroderma.3: Erythema covering >90% BSA with associated symptoms (e.g., pruritus or tenderness); limiting self care ADL
Erythroderma.4: Erythema covering >90% BSA with associated fluid or electrolyte abnormalities; ICU care or burn unit indicated

Fat atrophy.2: Covering 10-30% BSA and associated with erythema or tenderness; limiting instrumental ADL
Fat atrophy.3: Covering >30% BSA; associated with erythema or tenderness; limiting self-care ADL

Hirsutism.1: In women, increase in length, thickness or density of hair in a male distribution that the patient is able to camouflage by periodic shaving, bleaching, or removal of hair
Hirsutism.2: In women, increase in length, thickness or density of hair in a male distribution that requires daily shaving or consistent destructive means of hair removal to camouflage; associated with psychosocial impact

Hyperhidrosis.1: Limited to one site (palms, soles, or axillae); self care interventions
Hyperhidrosis.2: Involving >1 site; patient seeks medical intervention; associated with psychosocial impact
Hyperhidrosis.3: Generalized involving sites other than palms, soles, or axillae; associated with electrolyte/hemodynamic imbalance

Hypertrichosis.1: Increase in length, thickness or density of hair that the patient is either able to camouflage by periodic shaving or removal of hairs or is not concerned enough about the overgrowth to use any form of hair removal
Hypertrichosis.2: Increase in length, thickness or density of hair at least on the usual exposed areas of the body [face (not limited to beard/moustache area) plus/minus arms] that requires frequent shaving or use of destructive means of hair removal to camouflage; associated with psychosocial impact.

Hypohidrosis.3: Increase in body temperature; limiting self care ADL

Lipohypertrophy.2: Covering 10-30% BSA and associated tenderness; limiting instrumental ADL
Lipohypertrophy.3: Covering >30% BSA and associated tenderness and narcotics or NSAIDs indicated; lipohypertrophy; limiting self care ADL

Nail discoloration.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated

Nail loss.1: Asymptomatic separation of the nail bed from the nail plate or nail loss
Nail loss.2: Symptomatic separation of the nail bed from the nail plate or nail loss; limiting instrumental ADL

Nail ridging.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated

Pain of skin.3: Severe pain; limiting self care ADL

Palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia syndro.1: Minimal skin changes or dermatitis (e.g., erythema, edema, or hyperkeratosis) without pain
Palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia syndro.2: Skin changes (e.g., peeling, blisters, bleeding, edema, or hyperkeratosis) with pain; limiting instrumental ADL
Palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia syndro.3: Severe skin changes (e.g., peeling, blisters, bleeding, edema, or hyperkeratosis) with pain; limiting self care ADL

Periorbital edema.2: Indurated or pitting edema; topical intervention indicated
Periorbital edema.3: Edema associated with visual disturbance; increased intraocular pressure, glaucoma or retinal hemorrhage; optic neuritis; diuretics indicated; operative intervention indicated

Photosensitivity.1: Painless erythema and erythema covering <10% BSA
Photosensitivity.3: Erythema covering >30% BSA and erythema with blistering; photosensitivity; oral corticosteroid therapy indicated; pain control indicated (e.g., narcotics or NSAIDs)

Pruritus.1: Mild or localized; topical intervention indicated
Pruritus.2: Intense or widespread; intermittent; skin changes from scratching (e.g. edema, papulation, excoriations, lichenification, oozing/crusts); oral intervention indicated; limiting instrumental ADL
Pruritus.3: Intense or widespread; constant; limiting self care ADL or sleep; oral corticosteroid or immunosuppressive therapy indicated

Purpura.1: Combined area of lesions covering <10% BSA
Purpura.2: Combined area of lesions covering 10-30% BSA; bleeding with trauma
Purpura.3: Combined area of lesions covering >30% BSA; spontaneous bleeding

Rash acneiform.1: Papules and/or pustules covering <10% BSA, which may or may not be associated with symptoms of pruritus or tenderness
Rash acneiform.2: Papules and/or pustules covering 10-30% BSA, which may or may not be associated with symptoms of pruritus or tenderness; associated with psychosocial impact; limiting instrumental ADL
Rash acneiform.3: Papules and/or pustules covering >30% BSA, which may or may not be associated with symptoms of pruritus or tenderness; limiting self care ADL; associated with local superinfection with oral antibiotics indicated
Rash acneiform.4: Papules and/or pustules covering any % BSA, which may or may not be associated with symptoms of pruritus or tenderness and are associated with extensive superinfection with IV antibiotics indicated; life-threatening consequences

Rash maculo-papular.1: Macules/papules covering <10% BSA with or without symptoms (e.g., pruritus, burning, tightness)
Rash maculo-papular.2: Macules/papules covering 10-30% BSA with or without symptoms (e.g., pruritus, burning, tightness); limiting instrumental ADL
Rash maculo-papular.3: Macules/papules covering >30% BSA with or without associated symptoms; limiting self care ADL

Scalp pain.3: Severe pain; limiting self care ADL

Skin atrophy.1: Covering <10% BSA; associated with telangiectasias or changes in skin color
Skin atrophy.2: Covering 10-30% BSA; associated with striae or adnexal structure loss

Skin hyperpigmentation.1: Hyperpigmentation covering <10% BSA; no psychosocial impact
Skin hyperpigmentation.2: Hyperpigmentation covering >10% BSA; associated psychosocial impact

Skin hypopigmentation.1: Hypopigmentation or depigmentation covering <10% BSA; no psychosocial impact
Skin hypopigmentation.2: Hypopigmentation or depigmentation covering >10% BSA; associated psychosocial impact

Skin induration.1: Mild induration, able to move skin parallel to plane (sliding) and perpendicular to skin (pinching up)
Skin induration.2: Moderate induration, able to slide skin, unable to pinch skin; limiting instrumental ADL
Skin induration.3: Severe induration, unable to slide or pinch skin; limiting joint movement or orifice (e.g., mouth, anus); limiting self care ADL
Skin induration.4: Generalized; associated with signs or symptoms of impaired breathing or feeding

Skin ulceration.1: Combined area of ulcers <1 cm; nonblanchable erythema of intact skin with associated warmth or edema
Skin ulceration.2: Combined area of ulcers 1 - 2 cm; partial thickness skin loss involving skin or subcutaneous fat
Skin ulceration.3: Combined area of ulcers >2 cm; full-thickness skin loss involving damage to or necrosis of subcutaneous tissue that may extend down to fascia
Skin ulceration.4: Any size ulcer with extensive destruction, tissue necrosis, or damage to muscle, bone, or supporting structures with or without full thickness skin loss

Stevens-Johnson syndrome.3: Skin sloughing covering <10% BSA with associated signs (e.g., erythema, purpura, epidermal detachment and mucous membrane detachment)
Stevens-Johnson syndrome.4: Skin sloughing covering 10 - 30% BSA with associated signs (e.g., erythema, purpura, epidermal detachment and mucous membrane detachment)

Telangiectasia.2: Telangiectasias covering >10% BSA; associated with psychosocial impact

Toxic epidermal necrolysis.4: Skin sloughing covering >=30% BSA with associated symptoms (e.g., erythema, purpura, or epidermal detachment)

Urticaria.1: Urticarial lesions covering <10% BSA; topical intervention indicated
Urticaria.2: Urticarial lesions covering 10 - 30% BSA; oral intervention indicated
Urticaria.3: Urticarial lesions covering >30% BSA; IV intervention indicated

Skin and subcutaneous tissue disorders -.1: Asymptomatic or mild symptoms; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Skin and subcutaneous tissue disorders -.2: Moderate; minimal, local or noninvasive intervention indicated; limiting age-appropriate instrumental ADL
Skin and subcutaneous tissue disorders -.3: Severe or medically significant but not immediately life-threatening; hospitalization or prolongation of existing hospitalization indicated; disabling; limiting self care ADL

Menopause.3: Menopause occurring before age 40 years of age

Social circumstances - Other, specify.1: Asymptomatic or mild symptoms; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Social circumstances - Other, specify.2: Moderate; minimal, local or noninvasive intervention indicated; limiting age-appropriate instrumental ADL
Social circumstances - Other, specify.3: Severe or medically significant but not immediately life-threatening; hospitalization or prolongation of existing hospitalization indicated; disabling; limiting self care ADL

Surgical and medical procedures - Other,.1: Asymptomatic or mild symptoms; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Surgical and medical procedures - Other,.2: Moderate; minimal, local or noninvasive intervention indicated; limiting age-appropriate instrumental ADL
Surgical and medical procedures - Other,.3: Severe or medically significant but not immediately life-threatening; hospitalization or prolongation of existing hospitalization indicated; disabling; limiting self care ADL

Flushing.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Flushing.2: Moderate symptoms; medical intervention indicated; limiting instrumental ADL
Flushing.3: Symptomatic, associated with hypotension and/or tachycardia; limiting self care ADL

Hematoma.2: Minimally invasive evacuation or aspiration indicated
Hematoma.3: Transfusion, radiologic, endoscopic, or elective operative intervention indicated

Hot flashes.3: Severe symptoms; limiting self care ADL

Hypertension.1: Prehypertension (systolic BP 120 - 139 mm Hg or diastolic BP 80 - 89 mm Hg)
Hypertension.2: Stage 1 hypertension (systolic BP 140 - 159 mm Hg or diastolic BP 90-99 mm Hg); medical intervention indicated; recurrent or persistent (>=24 hrs); symptomatic increase by >20 mm Hg (diastolic) or to >140/90 mm Hg if previously WNL; monotherapy indicated. Pediatric: recurrent or persistent (>=24 hrs) BP >ULN; monotherapy indicated
Hypertension.3: Stage 2 hypertension (systolic BP >= 160 mm Hg or diastolic BP >=100 mm Hg); medical intervention indicated; more than one drug or more intensive therapy than previously used indicated Pediatric: Same as adult
Hypertension.4: Life-threatening consequences (e.g. malignant hypertension, transient or permanent neurologic deficit, hypertensive crisis); urgent intervention indicated Pediatric: Same as adult

Lymph leakage.3: Severe symptoms; radiologic, endoscopic or elective operative intervention indicated

Lymphedema.2: Marked discoloration; leathery skin texture; papillary formation; limiting instrumental ADL
Lymphedema.3: Severe symptoms; limiting self care ADL

Lymphocele.1: Asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Lymphocele.3: Severe symptoms; radiologic, endoscopic or elective operative intervention indicated

Peripheral ischemia.2: Brief (<24 hrs) episode of ischemia managed non-surgically and without permanent deficit
Peripheral ischemia.3: Recurring or prolonged (>=24 hrs) and/or invasive intervention indicated
Peripheral ischemia.4: Life-threatening consequences; evidence of end organ damage; urgent operative intervention indicated

Superior vena cava syndrome.1: Asymptomatic; incidental finding of SVC thrombosis
Superior vena cava syndrome.2: Symptomatic; medical intervention indicated (e.g., anticoagulation, radiation or chemotherapy)
Superior vena cava syndrome.3: Severe symptoms; multi-modality intervention indicated (e.g., anticoagulation, chemotherapy, radiation, stenting)
Superior vena cava syndrome.4: Life-threatening consequences; urgent multi-modality intervention indicated (e.g., lysis, thrombectomy, surgery)

Thromboembolic event.2: Venous thrombosis (e.g., uncomplicated deep vein thrombosis), medical intervention indicated
Thromboembolic event.3: Thrombosis (e.g., uncomplicated pulmonary embolism [venous], non-embolic cardiac mural [arterial] thrombus), medical intervention indicated
Thromboembolic event.4: Life-threatening (e.g., pulmonary embolism, cerebrovascular event, arterial insufficiency); hemodynamic or neurologic instability; urgent intervention indicated

Vasculitis.3: Severe symptoms, medical intervention indicated (e.g., steroids)
Vasculitis.4: Life-threatening; evidence of peripheral or visceral ischemia; urgent intervention indicated

Visceral arterial ischemia.2: Brief (<24 hrs) episode of ischemia managed medically and without permanent deficit
Visceral arterial ischemia.3: Prolonged (>=24 hrs) or recurring symptoms and/or invasive intervention indicated
Visceral arterial ischemia.4: Life-threatening consequences; evidence of end organ damage; urgent operative intervention indicated

Vascular disorders - Other, specify.1: Asymptomatic or mild symptoms; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated
Vascular disorders - Other, specify.2: Moderate; minimal, local or noninvasive intervention indicated; limiting age-appropriate instrumental ADL
Vascular disorders - Other, specify.3: Severe or medically significant but not immediately life-threatening; hospitalization or prolongation of existing hospitalization indicated; disabling; limiting self care ADL
